overview: From 2025-10-01 to 2025-11-01, Sendo-labs/plugin-jupiter had 1 new PRs (0 merged), 0 new issues, and 2 active contributors.

topPRs.title: Add referral fee support (Legacy Swap) + live E2E scripts, docs, and config
topPRs.author: MonteCrypto999
topPRs.body:
# PR: Optional Referral Fees on Jupiter Legacy Swap

This PR adds **optional referral fees** on *Jupiter Legacy Swap* via `platformFeeBps` and `feeAccount`,
with clean **env-based config**, **tests**, and **runnable E2E examples** (simulation/signing).

---

## üß© Features

### Referral Fees

* Adds `platformFeeBps` to `/quote` when `REFERRAL_FEE_BPS > 0`.
* Derives `feeAccount` as the **ATA for the chosen mint** from `REFERRAL_FEE_RECEIVER`.
* **Modes:**

  * `sol_only`: collect fees only if SOL/WSOL is in the pair.
  * `smart`: prefer SOL if available, else input mint.
* Respects **ExactIn / ExactOut** rules and skips fees if constraints aren‚Äôt met.

---

## üß† Code Changes

* **`src/service.ts`**

  * Integrates `platformFeeBps` in quote and `feeAccount` in swap.
  * Handles mint selection and fee receiver ATA derivation.
* **`src/__tests__/integration.test.ts`**

  * Live-mode tests against Jupiter API (referral on/off, custom mint sample).
* **`src/scripts/e2e-mainnet.ts`**

  * E2E script using `.env` (can simulate and sign/send).
* **`local-e2e/` (gitignored)**

  * Local simulator for build/quote/swap, simulate, and sign via **Helius RPC**.
* **Docs & Config**

  * `README.md` and `env.example`: updated with clear config and E2E instructions.
  * `.gitignore`: ignores `local-e2e` and env files.

---

## ‚öôÔ∏è How to Use

### 1. Setup Environment

Copy `.env.example` ‚Üí `.env` and set:

```bash
REFERRAL_FEE_BPS=20
REFERRAL_MODE=sol_only
REFERRAL_FEE_RECEIVER=<fee receiver public key>
TEST_INPUT_MINT=So11111111111111111111111111111111111111112
TEST_OUTPUT_MINT=Dz9mQ9NzkBcCsuGPFJ3r1bS4wgqKMHBPiVuniW8Mbonk
TEST_INPUT_AMOUNT_ATOMIC=5000000      # 0.005 SOL
TEST_SLIPPAGE_BPS=150
# Optional (for simulation/signing)
HELIUS_RPC_URL=<url>
SIGNER_SECRET_KEY=[‚Ä¶]
SEND_TX=0
```

---

### 2. Run E2E Example

```bash
npm run build && node dist/scripts/e2e-mainnet.js
```

---

### 3. Local Simulator (ignored, for ops/dev)

Populate `local-e2e/.env.local` as above, then run:

```bash
npm run local:sim
```

---

## üß© Notes & Edge Cases

* **Error ‚ÄúInvalid token account / 0x1789 (6025)‚Äù**
  Usually a route/account issue.
  Ensure the **fee receiver‚Äôs ATA exists** for the selected mint (e.g., WSOL in `sol_only` mode).
  If absent, create the ATA or let Jupiter create it idempotently.
  Some routes may still fail in simulation‚Äîtry higher slippage or another route.

* **No Referral Program needed** for Legacy Swap.
  (Still required for Trigger API.)

---

## üîó References

* [[Jupiter Docs ‚Äì Add Fees to Swap](https://dev.jup.ag/docs/swap/add-fees-to-swap)](https://dev.jup.ag/docs/swap/add-fees-to-swap)
* [[ElizaOS ‚Äì Create a Plugin](https://docs.elizaos.ai/guides/create-a-plugin)](https://docs.elizaos.ai/guides/create-a-plugin)

---

## ‚úÖ Checklist

* [x] Referral fee applied only when `REFERRAL_FEE_BPS > 0` and valid `feeAccount`
* [x] `feeAccount` derived from `REFERRAL_FEE_RECEIVER` ATA for selected mint
* [x] Live integration tests against Jupiter API
* [x] E2E script with simulation/signing (HELIUS RPC)
* [x] `README` and `.env.example` updated
* [x] Local-only utilities ignored by git

topContributors.summary: standujar: Focused on foundational development, establishing several new systems and plugins this month. They delivered the initial implementation for the Sendo Worker in a significant PR (Sendo-labs/plugin-sendo-worker#1, +13194 lines) and also set up the initial project structure for the frontend (Sendo-labs/frontend#2) and the CryptoScore plugin (Sendo-labs/plugin-cryptoscore#1). Their work also included initializing the contributor tracking system (Sendo-labs/leaderboard#1) and adding JSON endpoints to it (Sendo-labs/leaderboard#4). This activity demonstrates a strong focus on bootstrapping new features and core infrastructure.

Neysixx: Drove significant foundational improvements in the Sendo-labs/frontend repository, focusing primarily on large-scale refactoring. Their most impactful contribution was a massive project-wide refactor to update the structure and configurations (Sendo-labs/frontend#1), involving over 34,000 line changes. Alongside this, Neysixx delivered new pages (Sendo-labs/frontend#7), improved the existing page structure (Sendo-labs/frontend#3), and resolved a critical build issue by adding missing dependencies (Sendo-labs/frontend#5). This activity demonstrates a clear focus on refactoring, which constituted the majority of their work.

xdrkush: This month, xdrkush made foundational contributions to the new `Sendo-labs/sendo-api` repository. They initiated the project with a significant PR (#1) that added over 21,000 lines of code, establishing the service's groundwork. Following this, they addressed an issue with buy/sell accounts in a subsequent fix (PR #3). Their efforts were primarily focused on a mix of feature work and bug fixes within this new API.

M4XGO: Focused on establishing foundational development workflows and release processes this month. They implemented a significant new CI/CD setup in Sendo-labs/reusable-workflows#1, adding over 1000 lines of configuration to create reusable workflows and manage releases. M4XGO also extended this automation to enable NPM publishing for a separate plugin via Sendo-labs/plugin-cryptoscore#2. Their work was concentrated entirely in configuration and documentation files, reflecting a clear focus on improving repository infrastructure and automation.

0xCanet: This month, 0xCanet's work was focused on establishing the new `Sendo-labs/frontend` repository. They merged a single, substantial pull request (Sendo-labs/frontend#1) that served as the initial commit for the project. This foundational work introduced over 9,200 lines of code across 111 files, setting up the new codebase.

0domart: This month, 0domart focused on core functionality for the Sendo-labs/spotlight repository, opening a pull request to implement SOL transfer logic (Sendo-labs/spotlight#1). This single, substantial contribution modified 12 files with over 1,500 lines of new code. The work shows a strong emphasis on quality and correctness, with a primary focus on building out the associated unit tests.

tionebDotsamapha: This month, tionebDotsamapha's work was centered on improving project documentation. Their sole merged pull request (Sendo-labs/sendo-api#2) updated the README file to English, a significant change of 71 lines that improves the project's accessibility. This contribution reflects a focus entirely on documentation.
